awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Advances in Experimental Political Science: Evanston, IL
awd_abstract_narration:
Experiments are a central methodology in political science. Scholars from every subfield regularly turn to experiments. Practitioners rely on experimental evidence in evaluating social programs, policies, institutions, and information provision. It is thus not surprising that experiments constitute an integral part of undergraduate and graduate curricula. Over the last five years, approaches to social science experimentation have evolved greatly, due in part to the "replication crisis" - that is, findings of low replication rates of experiments. At the same time, political scientists have expanded the reach of experiments by tapping new data sources (e.g., elite samples) and introducing methods that had previously received scant attention in the discipline (e.g., conjoint experiments).

In order to ensure that the discipline successfully navigates questions about the reliability and replicability of experiments and fully exploits methodological advances, the project would gather participants for a workshop, "Advances in Experimental Political Science." The workshop papers will later be published in a volume by the same name. This is a follow-up to a 2009 workshop on experimentation supported by the National Science Foundation, and the resulting publication of the widely-used Cambridge Handbook of Experimental Political Science. That workshop and volume came at a time when experiments were still an emergent methodology in political science. The aforementioned debates and developments mean that we are now at a crucial time to hold another workshop and publish a new collected volume.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Experiments are a central methodology in the social sciences. Scholars from every subfield regularly turn to experiments. Practitioners rely on experimental evidence in evaluating social programs, policies, institutions, and information provision. It is thus not surprising that experiments constitute an integral part of undergraduate and graduate curricula. Over the last decade, approaches to social science experimentation have evolved greatly, due in part to the “replication crisis” – that is, findings of low replication rates of experiments. At the same time, social scientists have expanded the reach of experiments by tapping new data sources (e.g., elite samples) and introducing new methods.

The project's goal was to ensure that the social sciences successfully navigate questions about the reliability and replicability of experiments and fully exploit methodological advances. The project hosted a workshop on Advances to Experimental Social Sciences that included nearly 100 faculty and graduate students. The participants included a diverse set of individuals in terms of demographics, institutional affiliations, and career stages. It included presentations and discussions as well as mentoring activities. A number of collaborations grew out of the workshop. The most direct product was an edited volume published in 2021 by Cambridge University Press entitled Advances in Experimental Political Science. Additionally, a forthcoming authored book (by the PI) is being published by Cambridge University Press entitled Experimental Thinking: A Primer on Social Science Experiments.

These books provide state-of-the-art reviews of best practices in light of developments in experimental social science. Further, the workshop and books help with educating the next generation of students. They make new methods accessible to applied researchers and practitioners who rely on experiments for evaluative purposes. Additionally, scholars can learn from the books how to better assess experimental evidence and credibly communicate relevant findings to broad audiences across social, political, and economic domains.

Modified by: James N Druckman
